www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The removal from river channels of silt, sand and gravel brought in by streams and surface runoff in order to re-establish their natural width and depth; sometimes it also involves cutting down by scythe the vegetation growth and grasses on banks.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: channel clearing

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An injury or harm impairing the function or condition of a person or thing.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: damage

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The unconsolidated material that covers a gently sloping zone, typically with a concave profile, extending landward from the low-water line to the place where there is a definite change in material or physiographic from (such as a cliff), or to the line of permanent vegetation (usually the effective limit of the highest storm waves); a shore of body of water, formed and washed by waves or tides, usually covered by sand or gravel, and lacking a bare rocky surface. (Source: BJGEO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: beach

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The act of boring holes in the earth for finding water or oil, for geologic surveys, etc. (Source: ZINZAN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: drilling

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: pozzo per trattamento acque di falda
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: pozzo per trattamento acque di falda
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: depollution well

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: تبادل مائي بين مكمن جوفي ونهر سطحي
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: river-groundwater exchange
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: تبادل مائي بين مكمن جوفي ونهر سطحي

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A device which transfers heat from a cooler reservoir to a hotter one, expending mechanical energy in the process, especially when the main purpose is to heat the hot reservoir rather than refrigerate the cold one. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: heat pump

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: توليد الطاقه الكهربائيه باستخدام الطاقة الشمسية
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The energy transmitted from the sun in the form of electromagnetic radiation. The most successful examples of energy extraction from the sun are so far solar cells used in satellites and solar collectors used to heat water. (Source: MGH / ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: solar energy
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: توليد الطاقه الكهربائيه باستخدام الطاقة الشمسية

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: توليد الطاقه الكهربائيه باستخدام الحركة الامتدادية للمياه
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Mechanical power, which may be converted to electrical power, generated by the rise and fall of ocean tides. The possibilities of utilizing tidal power have been studied for many generations, but the only feasible schemes devised so far are based on the use of one or more tidal basins, separated from the sea by dams (known as barrages), and of hydraulic turbines through which water passes on its way between the basins and the sea. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: tidal power
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: توليد الطاقه الكهربائيه باستخدام الحركة الامتدادية للمياه

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The free renewable source of energy provided by falling water that drives the turbines. Hydropower is the most important of the regenerable energy sources because of its highest efficiency at the energy conversion. There are two types of hydroelectric power plants: a) run-of-river power plants for the use of affluent water; b) storage power plants (power stations with reservoir) where the influx can be regulated with the help of a reservoir. Mostly greater differences in altitudes are being used, like mountain creeks. Power stations with reservoirs are generally marked by barrages with earth fill dam or concrete dams. Though hydropower generally can be called environmentally acceptable, there exist also some problems: a) change of groundwater level and fill up of the river bed with rubble. b) Risk of dam breaks. c) Great demand for land space for the reservoir. d) Diminution, but partly also increase of value of recreation areas. As the hydropowers of the world are limited, the world energy demand however is rising, finally the share of hydropower will decrease. (Source: PORT / PHC / PZ)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydroelectric energy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Energy obtained from natural or artificial waterfalls, either directly by turning a water wheel or turbine, or indirectly by generating electricity in a dynamo driven by a turbine. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water power

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An energy produced by tapping the earth's internal heat. At present, the only available technologies to do this are those that extract heat from hydrothermal convection systems, where water or steam transfer the heat from the deeper part of the earth to the areas where the energy can be tapped. The amount of pollutants found in geothermal vary from area to area but may contain arsenic, boron, selenium, lead, cadmium, and fluorides. They also may contain hydrogen sulphide, mercury, ammonia, radon, carbon dioxide, and methane. (Source: KOREN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: geothermal energy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: طاقة الرياح باستخدام طواحين هوائية كبيرة
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Energy extracted from wind, traditionally in a windmill, but increasingly by more complicated designes including turbines, usually to produce electricity but also for water pumping. The power available from wind is proportional to the area swept by the rotating place and the cube of the wind velocity, but less than half the available power can be recovered. (Source: BRACK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: wind power
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: طاقة الرياح باستخدام طواحين هوائية كبيرة

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Structures that intercept or obstruct the natural flow of groundwater and provide storage for water underground. Their use is in areas where flows of groundwater vary considerably during the course of the year, from very high flows following rain to negligible flows during the dry season. The basic principle of the groundwater dam is that instead of storing the water in surface reservoirs, water is stored underground. The main advantages of water storage in groundwater dams is that evaporation losses are much less for water stored underground. Further, risk of contamination of the stored water from the surface is reduced because as parasites cannot breed in underground water (CSEIND).
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: groundwater dam

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Permeable water-bearing formation capable of yielding exploitable quantities of water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: aquifer

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The filling of groundwater aquifers by rain and melting snow percolating into the ground and saturating the pores between rock and soil particles.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: groundwater natural recharge

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Process by which water is added from outside to the zone of saturation of an aquifer, either directly into a formation, or indirectly by way of another formation.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: groundwater artificial recharge

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Reappearance above ground, at the end of its underground course, of a surface water flow which disappeared underground.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: resurgence

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Closed depression or doline into which all or part of a stream disappears underground.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: swallow-hole

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) A German rendering of a Serbo-Croat term referring to the terrain created by limestone solution and characterized by a virtual absence of surface drainage, a series of surface hollows, depressions and fissures, collapse structures, and an extensive subterranean drainage network. 2) A type of topography that is formed on limestone, gypsum, and other rocks by dissolution, and that is characterized by sinkholes, caves, and underground drainage. Etymology: German, from the Yugoslavian territory Krs; type locality, a limestone plateau in the Dinaric Alps of northwestern Yugoslavia and northeastern Italy. (Source: WHIT / BJGEO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: karst

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Ground water that is hydrologically connected to a surface stream that is present in permeable geologic material, usually small rocks and gravel.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: alluvial groundwater

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: ماء غير محدد الملكية او شائع
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A body of water that is owned and maintained by an individual or entity other than the national government. (Source: OED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: non-demesnial water
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: ماء غير محدد الملكية او شائع

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A body of water that is owned and maintained by a national governmental body or agency. (Source: OED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: demesnial water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: diritto dei proprietari rivieraschi su un corso d'acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: diritto dei proprietari rivieraschi su un corso d'acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: riverside rights

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Threatened, vulnerable or endangered species which are protected from extinction by preventive measures.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: protected species

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Methods to control land surface features to prevent erosion by surface water or precipitation runoff.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: erosion fighting

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Physical expression of human activities that could change the status of the environment in space and time (discharge, abstraction, environmental changes, etc...).
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pressures

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The state, character or behavior of a person viewed as a member of the ecosystem with attendant rights and responsibilities, especially the responsibility to maintain ecological integrity and the right to exist in a healthy environment. (Source: TOE / RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: environmental citizenship

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Official statements of principles, intentions, values, and objective which are based on legislation and the governing authority of a state and which serve as a guide for the operations of governmental and private activities in environmental affairs. (Source: UNUN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: environmental policy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The educational process that deals with the human interrelationships with the environment and that utilizes an interdisciplinary problem-solving approach with value clarification. Concerned with education progress of knowledge, understanding, attitudes, skills, and commitment for environmental problems and considerations. The need for environmental education is continuous, because each new generation needs to learn conservation for itself. (Source: UNUN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: environmental education

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A designated area or an administrative division of a city, county or larger geographical territory that is formulated according to some biological, political, economic or demographic criteria. (Source: RHW / ISEP)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: region

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The assessment of the concentration of pollutants for a given time in a given point.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pollution measurement

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A process in which a solid, especially a metal, is eaten away and changed by a chemical action.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: corrosion

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The science or philosophy of law. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: jurisprudence

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Discharge of sediment material of a stream at a given cross section.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sediment discharge

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A judicial contest, a judicial controversy, a suit at law. (Source: BLACK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: litigation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: International agreement on a specific topic. (Source: RRDA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: convention

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Rise in streamflow to a maximum crest, and its subsequent recession, caused by a period of precipitation, snow melt, dam failure or hydroelectric plant releases.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flood wave

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Flood magnitude which has a one chance in one hundred of being exceeded in any future one-year period. The occurrence of floods is assumed to be random in time, or a regularity of occurrence is implied. The exceeding of a one percent chance flood is no guarantee, therefore, that a similar size flood will not occur next week. The risk of epxerienceing a large flood within time periods longer than one year increases in a nonadditive fashion. For example, the risk of exceeding a one percent chance flood (i.e., a one hundred year flood) one or more times during a thirty-year period is 25 percent and during a seventy-year period is 50 percent. (Source: SRHNOA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hundred-year flood

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The study of the motion of a fluid and of the interactions of the fluid with its boundaries, especially in the incompressible inviscid case.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrodynamics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The water characteristic of an area.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrologic profile

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) Rise, usually brief, in the water level in a stream to a peak from which the water level recedes at a slower rate. 2) Relatively high flow as measured by stage height or discharge. 3) Rising tide.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flood

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) Science that deals with the waters above and below the land surfaces of the Earth, their occurrence, circulation and distribution, both in time and space, their biological, chemical and physical properties, their reaction with their environment, including their relation to living beings. 2) Science that deals with the processes governing the depletion and replenishment of the water resources of the land areas of the Earth, and treats the various phases of the hydrological cycle. (Source: UNESCO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Law inspired by old Roman Law, the primary feature of which was that laws were written into a collection; codified, and not determined, as is common law, by judges. The principle of civil law is to provide all citizens with an accessible and written collection of the laws which apply to them and which judges must follow. (Source: DUHA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: civil law

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Financial compensation, reimbursement or security for damages or loss offered by a government, insurance policy or contractual agreement under specified conditions and for specific casualties. (Source: BLD)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: indemnity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Body of law created by administrative agencies in the form of rules, regulations, orders and decisions to carry out regulatory powers and duties of such agencies. (Source: BLACK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: administrative law

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A science that deals with poisons, their actions, their detection, and the treatment of the conditions they produce. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: toxicology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Portions of land protected by special restrictions and laws for the conservation of the natural environment. They include large tracts of land set aside for the protection of wildlife and its habitat; areas of great natural beauty or unique interest; areas containing rare forms of plant and animal life; areas representing unusual geologic formation; places of historic and prehistoric interest; areas containing ecosystems of special importance for scientific investigation and study; and areas which safeguard the needs of the biosphere. (Source: DODERO / WPR)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: protected area

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A level or gently sloping tract or a slightly undulating land surface produced by extensive deposition of alluvium, usually adjacent to a river that periodically overflows its banks; it may be situated on a flood plain, a delta, or an alluvial fan.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: alluvial plain

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any low-lying land bordered by higher ground; especially an elongate, relatively large, gently sloping depression of the Earth's surface, commonly situated between two mountains or between ranges of hills or mountains, and often containing a stream with an outlet. It is usually developed by stream erosion, but may be formed by faulting. (Source: BJGEO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: valley

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The plants of an area considered in general or as communities, but not taxonomically; the total plant cover in a particular area or on the Earth as a whole. 2) The total mass of plant life that occupies a given area. (Source: ALL / MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: vegetation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The science dealing with the adverse effects of chemical, physical agents, and natural products on populations and communities of plants, animals and human beings. (Source: GILP96)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: ecotoxicology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Quality of some substances or preparations which present or may present immediate or delayed risks for one or more sectors of the environment.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: ecotoxicity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A body of persons associated for the regulation of a common economic activity by means of a special organization. (Source: SHOOX / ZINZAN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: association

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) Liquid flowing out of a container or other system. 2) Water or waste water flowing out of a reservoir or treatment plant. 3) Outflowing branch of a main stream or lake.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: effluent

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Materials generally discarded from industrial operations or derived from manufacturing processes.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: industrial effluent

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The liquid wastes deriving from domestic, commercial and industrial activities of an urban settlement.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: urban effluent

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The branch of science that deals with the geometric description of crystals and their internal arrangement. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: crystallography

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The range of political, organizational and administrative processes through which communities articulate their interests, their input is absorbed, decisions are made and implemented, and decision makers are held accountable in the development and management of water resources and delivery of water services at different levels of society
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: Water governance

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An attached growth waste water treatment system consisting of closely spaced discs up to 3m diameter, or random plastic media in circular wire cages, used in aerobic sewage treatment, that are carried by a horizontal shaft just above the surface of the se
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biological disc

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Separation of colloidal or very fine solid materials by filtration through microporous or semipermeable mediums.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: ultrafiltration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The movement of water between the oceans, ground surface and atmosphere by evaporation, precipitation and the activity of living organisms, as one of the mayor biogeochemical cycles. Each day water evaporates from the oceans and is carried in the air from the sea over the land, which receives it as precipitation, and finally returns from the land to the sea through rivers, thus completing the cycle. (Source: ALLa)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water cycle

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The law of European Community (as opposed to the national laws of the member states.) It consists of the treaties establishing the EC (together with subsequent amending treaties) community legislation, and decisions of the court of justice of the European Communities. Any provision of the treaties or of community legislation that is directly applicable or directly effective in a member state forms part of the law of that state and prevails over its national law in the event of any inconsistency between the two. (Source: DICLAW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: community law

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A specialty membrane filtration process which rejects solutes larger than approximately one nanometer (10 angstroms) in size.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: nanofiltration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The separation or removal from a liquid of particulates and microorganisms in the size range of 0.1 to 0.2 microns in diameter.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: microfiltration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A thin tissue that encloses or lines biological cells, organs, or other structures. It consists of a double layer of lipids with protein molecules between the two layers. Membranes are permeable to water and fat-soluble substances but not to such polar molecules as sugars. (Source: UVAROV)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: membrane

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The appraisal or determination of the actual effects resulting from technological or natural disaster.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: damage assessment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Treating with oxygen.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: oxygenation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A measurement of the amount of pollution entering an ecosystem.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pollution load

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Area that is subject to threatening processes and is likely to become endangered unless the threatening factors cease to operate.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: vulnerable area

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The principle that those causing pollution should meet the costs to which it gives rise. (Source: BRACK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: polluter-pays principle

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A chemical reaction that increases the oxygen content of a compound. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: oxidation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A co-ordinated body of methods or plan of procedures for levying compulsory charges for the purpose of raising revenue. (Source: ISEP / EFP)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: tax system

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An amount of money demanded by a government for its support or for specific facilities or services, most frequently levied upon income, property or sales. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: tax

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A systematic series of actions performed by a person or computer on data elements including classifying, sorting, calculating, summarizing, transmitting, retrieving and receiving. (Source: JON)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: information processing

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process of accumulating, classifying and disseminating information, often to support the claim or data given in a book or article. (Source: OED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: documentation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The making of maps and charts for the purpose of visualizing spatial distributions over various areas of the earth.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: cartography

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any action taken to prevent lake deterioration or return a lake system to an unimpaired state or condition.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: lake restoration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The planning, design, construction, and maintenance of fixed structures and ground facilities for industry, transportation, use and control of water or occupancy.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: civil engineering

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Cutting down by scythe or machine at intervals the vegetation growth and grasses on banks and berms of irrigation and drainage channels or cropped areas.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: weeds cleaning

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The return of a degraded waterway to the original state in regard to physical structure and stability, functionality, water quality, flow regime, and plant and animal communities.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: river restoration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The cutting off or removal of dead or living parts or branches of a plant to improve shape or growth. (Source: AMHERa)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pruning

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Vertical sliding gate or valve to regulate the flow of water in a channel or lock. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: lock

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Dams designed to maintain water levels high enough for navigation. They are not designed for flood control purposes and have little effect on high water. The dams impound water that would naturally flow away. They divide the river into large flat reaches that cause permanent covering of floodplain areas that otherwise would flood only seasonally or occasionally. (Source: ASSRM)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: navigation dam

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Structure constructed in a valley across a watercourse or stream channel for impounding water or creating a reservoir.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: dam

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A man made structure built to enable fish to swim upstream over obstacles such as weirs. It consists usually of a series of small steps and pools which fish can swim up or jump over.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: fish way

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process which remove pollutants not adequately removed by secondary treatment, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus; accomplished by means of sand filters, microstraining, or other methods (referring to wastewater treatment). (Source: WQA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: tertiary treatment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process in which sunlight, bacterial action and oxygen cause self-purification in waste water, Usually taking place in a shallow pond, or system of such ponds. (Source: TOEa)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: lagooning

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A device that removes some suspended solids from sewage. Air and bacteria decompose additional wastes filtering through the sand so that cleaner water drains from the bed. (Source: LEE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: bacterial bed

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The act or process in which a section of the ground is freed from pollution or any type of contamination, often through natural processes. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: purification through the soil

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An embankment dam in which more than half of the total volume is formed of compacted fine grained material.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: earth dam

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A dam and associated reservoir used to produce electrical power by letting the high-pressure water behind the dam flow through and drive a turbogenerator.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydroelectric dam

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The kind of flow that occurs in a closed channel.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: closed pipe flow

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Flow between laminar and turbulent flow, usually between a pipe Reynolds number of 2000 and 4000.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: transitional flow

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A flow in which the velocity of the fluid at a particular fixed point does not change with time.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: steady flow

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any marine environment, from pond to ocean, in which plants and animals interact with the chemical and physical features of the environment. (Source: GILP96)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: marine ecosystem

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A specified geographical tract of the Earth's surface including all its attributes, comprising its geology, superficial deposits, topography, hydrology, soils, flora and fauna, together with the results of past and present human activity, to the extent that these attributes exert a significant influence on the present and future land utilization. (Source: WHIT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: land

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The production of a chemical reaction by passing an electric current through an electrolyte. In electrolysis, positive ions migrate to the cathode and negative ions to the anode. (Source: DICCHE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: electrolysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) Decomposition or alteration of a chemical substance by water. 2) In aqueous solutions of electrolytes, the reactions of cations with water to produce a weak base or of anions to produce a weak acid. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrolysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An oxidizing chemical change, where an element's positive valence is increased (electron loss), accompanied by a simultaneous reduction of an associated element (electron gain). (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: oxidation-reduction

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The ability of a substance to form a solution with another substance. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: solubility

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Substance, generally a liquid, capable of dissolving another substance. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: solvent

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The force acting on the surface of a liquid, tending to minimize the area of the surface; quantitatively, the force that appears to act across a line of unit length on the surface. Also known as interfacial force; interfacial tension; surface intensity. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: surface tension

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The variability among living organisms from all sources, inter alia, terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosystems and the ecological complexes of which they are a part: this includes diversity within species, between species and of ecosystems. It includes cultivated species and varieties and agricultural ecosystems as well as natural ecosystems and their components. (Source: GOBLUK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biodiversity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A region of relatively uniform environmental conditions, occupied by a given plant community and its associated animal community.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biotope

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The 15 nations (Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, the UK, Austria, Finland and Sweden) that have joined together to form an economic community with common monetary, political and social aspirations. The EU came into being on 1 November 1993 according to the terms of the Maastricht Treaty; it comprises the three European Communities, extended by the adoption of a common foreign and security policy which requires cooperation between member states in foreign policy and security and cooperation in justice and home affairs. (Source: DICLAW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: European Union

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The mass of living or organic material, usually expressed as dry weight per unit area.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biomass

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A sequence of organisms on successive trophic levels within a community, through which energy is transferred by feeding; energy enters the food chain during fixation by primary producers (mainly green plants) and passes to the herbivores (primary consumers) and then to the carnivores (secondary and tertiary consumers). (Source: LBC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: food chain

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An economy in which prices, incomes etc. are determined centrally by government rather than through the operation of the free market, and in which industrial production is governed by an overall national plan.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic planning

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The use of methods, strategy, intrigue, decision making and power by governments and their representatives to achieve goals in policy making or governmental affairs in a worldwide or international arena. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: international politics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A definite course of action adopted and pursued by a government, political party or enterprise pertaining to the production, distribution and use of income, wealth and commodities. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic policy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The state of nations and the historical processes of change experienced by them, the extent to which the resources of a nation are brought into productive use; the concept of development subsumes associated social, cultural and political changes as well as welfare measures. (Source: GOOD)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic development

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A permanent irrigation conduit constructed to convey water from the source of supply to one or more farms. (Source: NALMS)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: irrigation canal

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Mesures including annual river inspections, removal of obstructions, vegetative management and minor erosion control works.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: river maintenance

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A building where grain is crushed into flour. (Source: CAMB)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mill

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Protection of land areas from overflow, or minimization of damage caused by flooding.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flood protection

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: settorializzazione di un corso di acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: settorializzazione di un corso di acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: watercourse sectoring

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: تعزيز مائي لموسم انخفاض المنسوب المائي
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: low water support
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: تعزيز مائي لموسم انخفاض المنسوب المائي

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Artificial conveyance of water from one area to another one. (Source: CHAP)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water transfer

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An artificial watercourse of uniform dimensions designed for navigation, drainage or irrigation.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: canal

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: النقص المائي بالنسنة للطلب او الحاجة الغعلية
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water stress
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: النقص المائي بالنسنة للطلب او الحاجة الغعلية

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An irrigation system in which the water is not pumped but flows in ditches or pipes and is distributed by gravity.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: gravity irrigation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any wastewater which is discharged from trade or industrial premises, other than domestic waste water and run-off rain water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: industrial waste water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water carrying waste material from agricultural activities (animal manure, plant stalks, hulls and leaves, etc.).
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: agricultural waste water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water which falls as rain from clouds.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: rain water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water in the lithosphere in solid, liquid, or gaseous form. It includes all water beneath the land surface and beneath bodies of surface water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: underground water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Moving waters like rivers and streams. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flowing water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Wastewater principally derived from households, business buildings, institutions, etc., which may or may not contain surface runoff, groundwater or storm water. (Source: WWC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: domestic waste water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An irrigation method in which water is applied below the ground surface either by raising the water table within or near the root zone or by using a buried perforated or porous pipe system that discharged directly into the root zone.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: subsurface irrigation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Used water, or water that is not needed, which is permitted to escape, or unavoidably escapes from canals, ditches, reservoirs or other bodies of water, for which the owners of these structures are legally responsible. (Source: WWC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: waste water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water, salty between the concentrations of fresh water and sea water; usually 5-10 parts x thousand.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: brackish water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The presence of one or more contaminants upon or within an area of land, or its constituents. (Source: Landy)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: land pollution

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Pollution as a result of industrial processes and manufacturing.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: industrial pollution

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Pollution caused by small solid particles which are held in suspension in water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: suspended pollutant

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Expenses incurred as a result of some violation of ecological integrity either by an enterprise that implements a program to rectify the situation, or by society or the ecosystem as a whole when no person or enterprise is held liable. (Source: IEC / ECH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: environmental cost

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The planning, design, construction, and maintenance of fixed structures and ground facilities for industry, transportation, use and control of water or occupancy.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: civil engineering

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A branch of chemistry dealing with the study of composition, reaction, properties, etc. of organic compounds. (Source: LEE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: organic chemistry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The EU Water Framework Directive imposes as a first step to produce a presentation report on the characteristics of the river basin district, which shall include the following elements: delimitation of water bodies, including identification of artificial water bodies and provisional identification of heavily modified water bodies; analysis of usage (technical and economic data), pressures and their impact on environments, and identification of water use; analysis of pricing practices and the recovery of the costs of services. (WFD)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: characterisation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Measures and controls to prevent damage and degradation of the environment, including the sustainability of its living resources. (Source: UNUN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: environmental protection

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Ground water vertically in direct contact with atmosphere.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: free groundwater

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The quantitative and qualitative identification, study, and evaluation of the nature of an economy or a system of organization or operation. (Source: ISEP / RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any tool or method used by an organization to achieve general developmental goals in the production of, or in the regulation of, material resources. (Source: OED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic instrument

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any effort, work, function or sphere of action pertaining to the production of goods, services or any other resource with exchange value. (Source: RHW / NDECON)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic activity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: قناة لنقل الماء من مكان إلىأخر
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A channel for supplying water; often underground, but treated architecturally on high arches when crossing valleys or low ground.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: aqueduct
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: قناة لنقل الماء من مكان إلىأخر

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Artificial or natural area of water, used for storing water for domestic or industrial use.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water reservoir

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Collecting groundwater into pipes or canals.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: groundwater catchment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: captazione delle acque superficali / in superfice
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: captazione delle acque superficali / in superfice
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: stream impounding

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: protección de las captaciones de manantiales
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Area surrounding a water recovery plant in which certain forms of soil utilization are restricted or prohibited in order to protect the groundwater.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: protección de las captaciones de manantiales
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water catchment protection

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The amount of money paid per unit for a good or service. (Source: ODE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: price

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An enterprise concerned with the provision to the public of essentials, such as electricity or water. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: public service

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) To supply land with water so that crops and plants will grow or grow stronger. (Source: CAMB / WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: irrigation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) Removal of groundwater or surface water, or of water from structures, by gravity or pumping. 2) The discharge of water from a soil by percolation (the process by which surface water moves downwards through cracks, joints and pores in soil and rocks). (Source: MGH / WHIT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: drainage

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Science and technology involved in the management of water resources, in the control of erosion and in the removal of unwanted water. (Source: ECHO2)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: agricultural hydraulics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The art and science of growing plants. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: horticulture

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An ecological organization represented by the sum total of all living organisms in a prescribed ecosystem. (Source: SUPREM)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biocoenosis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The planting and care of woody plants, especially trees. (Source: AMHER)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: arboriculture

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Method of recording all the transactions affecting the financial condition of a business or organization.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: accounting

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The business of growing fruit and vegetables on a commercial scale. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: market gardening

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Crops that are grown for sale in the town markets or for export. They include coffee, cocoa, sugar, vegetables, peanuts and non-foods, like tobacco and cotton. Huge areas of countries in the developing world have been turned over to cash crops. Those countries with no mineral or oil resources depend on cash crops for foreign money, so that they can import materials do develop roads, for construction, or to buy Western consumer goods and, indeed, food. However, critics argue that cash crops are planted on land that would otherwise be used to grow food for the local community and say this is a cause of world famine. Cash crops, such as peanuts, can ruin the land if it is not left fallow after six years of harvests. Moreover, if the best agricultural land is used for cash crops, local farmers are forced to use marginal land to grow food for local consumption, and this has a further dramatic effect on the environment. (Source: WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: cash crop

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Freeing an area of land from weeds by several means, such as herbicides, tillage, burning, mowing, and crop competition. (Source: RRDA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: weed control

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A branch of agriculture concerned with the breeding and feeding of domestic animals. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: animal husbandry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Analytical determination of the nature and degree of toxicity. It is usually carried out by tests on laboratory animals (mostly mice and rats), bacteria, and cell tissue cultures and by studying the effects on human populations exposed to high levels at work or by accidents. The results of animal tests are extrapolated to humans. (Source: EPAGLO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: toxicity test

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: فحص السُمية على الجينات الوراثية للآحياء
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Testing the property of a substance of being able to induce genetic mutation. (Source: CONFERa)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mutagenicity testing
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: فحص السُمية على الجينات الوراثية للآحياء

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The amount of a substance required to produce an effect. (Source: CONFER)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: dosage

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The measurement of the compressibility of liquids.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: piezometry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The laboratory determination of the effects of substances upon specific living organisms.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biotest

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Equipment employed in analytical techniques. (Source: RRDA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: analytical equipment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: مطرح مياة المجمعات الحضرية لموسم المطري
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: ruscellamento urbano in tempo di pioggia
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: rejet urbain par temps de pluie
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: rejet urbain par temps de pluie
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: ruscellamento urbano in tempo di pioggia
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: wet weather urban runoff
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: مطرح مياة المجمعات الحضرية لموسم المطري

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The obtaining of small representative quantities of material for the purpose of analysis. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sampling

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: gestion de la demande en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: gestion de la demande en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water demand management refers to the implementation of policies or measures which serve to control or influence the amount of water used.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water demand management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: سياسة العرض و الطلب على الماء
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: sistema dell'offerta e della domanda di acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: systeme d'offre et de demande en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: systeme d'offre et de demande en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: sistema dell'offerta e della domanda di acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water supply and demand
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: سياسة العرض و الطلب على الماء

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water demand is defined as the volume of water requested by users to satisfy their needs. In a simplified way it is often considered equal to water abstraction, although conceptually the two terms do not have the same meaning.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water demand

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water in any of its forms, wherever located - atmosphere, surface or ground - which is or can be of value to man.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water resource

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: gestione delle fonti di acqua dolce
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: gestion de la ressource en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: gestion de la ressource en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: gestione delle fonti di acqua dolce
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water supply management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The degree of danger posed by a substance to animal or plant life. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: toxicity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A state of dynamic equilibrium between an organism and its environment in which all functions of mind and body are normal. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: health

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The science that deals with the principles and practices of good health. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hygiene

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: rete dei bacini delle acque sotterranee
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: rete dei bacini delle acque sotterranee
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: aquifer network

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A water filter which uses fine silica sand as a filter media.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sand filter

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A powdered, granular or pelleted form of amorphous carbon characterized by a very large surface area per unit volume because of an enormous number of fine pores. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: activated carbon

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Interconnected group of monitoring stations for the surveillance of pollution. (Source: RRDA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: monitoring network

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A process for removing particles from water by passing it through a porous barrier, such as a screen, membrane, sand or gravel. Often used in conjunction with a flocculant to settle contaminants. (Source: NEYWAT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water filtration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A porous material for separating suspended particulate matter from liquids by passing the liquid through the pores in the filter and sieving out the solids.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: filter

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A biological wastewater treatment technology used in chemical manufacturing facilities, solid waste processing plants, composting operations, and rendering plants. Biological systems use microorganisms that consume and destroy organic compounds as a food source. Source: SEVERN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biological filtration of water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The loss of nitrogen from soil by biological or chemical means. It is a gaseous loss, unrelated to loss by physical processes such as through leachates. 2) The breakdown of nitrates by soil bacteria, resulting in the release of free nitrogen. This process takes place under anaerobic conditions, such as are found in water-logged soil, and it reduces soil fertility. (Source: WRIGHT / ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: denitrification

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A machine that draws a fluid into itself through an entrance port and forces the fluid out through an exhaust port. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pump

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by filtering.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: suspended matter

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The amount of oxygen dissolved in a stream, river or lake is an indication of the degree of health of the stream and its ability to support a balanced aquatic ecosystem. The oxygen comes from the atmosphere by solution and from photosynthesis of water plants. The maximum amount of oxygen that can be held in solution in a stream is termed the saturation concentration and, as it is a function of temperature, the greater the temperature, the less the saturation amount. The discharge of an organic waste to a stream imposes an oxygen demand on the stream. If there is an excessive amount of organic matter, the oxidation of waste by microorganisms will consume oxygen more rapidly than it can be replenished. When this happens, the dissolved oxygen is depleted and results in the death of the higher forms of life. (Source: PORT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: dissolved oxygen

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A colourless gas with a faint tingling smell and taste. Atmospheric carbon dioxide is the source of carbon for plants. As carbon dioxide is heavier than air and does not support combustion, it is used in fire extinguishers. It is a normal constituent of the atmosphere, relatively innocuous in itself but playing an important role in the greenhouse effect. It is produced during the combustion of fossil fuels when the carbon content of the fuels reacts with the oxygen during combustion. It is also produced when living organisms respire. It is essential for plant nutrition and in the ocean phytoplankton is capable of absorbing and releasing large quantities of the gas. (Source: UVAROV / GILP96)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: carbon dioxide

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A characteristic of water caused by various salts, calcium, magnesium and iron (e.g., bicarbonates, sulfates, chlorides and nitrates).
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water hardness

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An intimate mixture of two substances, one of which, called the dispersed phase, is uniformly distributed in a finely divided state through the second substance, called the dispersion medium. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: colloid

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A process of pollution that occurs when a lake or stream becomes over-rich in plant nutrient; as a consequence it becomes overgrown in algae and other aquatic plants. The plants die and decompose. In decomposing the plants rob the water of oxygen and the lake, river or stream becomes lifeless. Nitrate fertilizers which drain from the fields, nutrients from animal wastes and human sewage are the primary causes of eutrophication. They have high biological oxygen demand (BOD). (Source: WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: eutrophication

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Chemical and physical methods to lessen discharges of most pollutants.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pollution control

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Technology applied or measure taken to reduce pollution and/or its impacts on the environment. The most commonly used technologies are scrubbers, noise mufflers, filters, incinerators, waste-water treatment facilities and composting of wastes.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pollution abatement

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A feature of the earth's surface that rises high above the base and has generally steep slopes and a relatively small summit area. Mountains are an important source of water, energy, minerals, forest and agricultural products, and recreation. They are storehouses of biological diversity and endangered species and an essential part of the global ecosystem. About 10% of the world's population depend on mountain resources and nearly half of these people are affected by the degradation of mountain watershed areas. (Source: MGH / WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mountain

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The indirect or direct alteration of the biological, thermal, physical, or radioactive properties of any medium in such a way as to create a hazard or potential hazard to human health or to the health, safety or welfare of any living species.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pollution

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any material transported by water which will ultimately settle to the bottom after the water loses its transporting power.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sediment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The act or process of forming or accumulating sediment in layers, including such processes as the separation of rock particles from the material from which the sediment is derived, the transportation of these particles to the site of deposition, the actua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sedimentation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A vegetation community dominated by trees and other woody shrubs, growing close enough together that the tree tops touch or overlap, creating various degrees of shade on the forest floor. It may produce benefits such as timber, recreation, wildlife habitat, etc. (Source: DUNSTE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: forest

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any terrestrial environment, from small to large, in which plants and animals interact with the chemical and physical features of the environment. (Source: GILP96)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: terrestrial ecosystem

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The filling or partial filling with silt of a reservoir that receives fine-grained sediment brought in by streams and surface runoff.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: silting up

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Area at the mouth of a river where it broadens into the sea, and where fresh and sea water intermingle to produce brackish water. The estuarine environment is very rich in wildlife, particularly aquatic, but it is very vulnerable to damage as a result of the actions of humans. (Source: WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: estuary

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: الحد التداخلي للمياة العذبة مع المالحة
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Surface separating a body of fresh water and one of brackish or salt water, taken somewhere within the transition zone between the two fluids.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: freshwater interface
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: الحد التداخلي للمياة العذبة مع المالحة

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An administrative body or system in which political direction and control is exercised over the community of a city, town or small district. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: local government

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water that is agreeable to drink, does not present health hazards and whose quality is normally regulated by legislation.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: drinking water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: acqua per uso industriale (acqua per uso industriale)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: acqua per uso industriale (acqua per uso industriale)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: industrial use water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water used in agriculture for irrigation and livestock. Livestock watering is only 1 percent of the total water withdrawal for agricultural use. Of all functional water uses, irrigation is the largest agricultural use of water. (Source: CORBIT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water for agricultural use

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Utilization of water by end users for a specific purpose within a territory, such as for domestic use, irrigation or industrial processing.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water use

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: gestión de los cursos de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: gestión de los cursos de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water stream management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The most common form of frozen precipitation, usually flakes or starlike crystals, matted ice needles, or combinations, and often rime-coated.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: snow

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water droplets or, rarely, ice crystals suspended in the air in sufficient concentration to reduce visibility appreciably. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: fog

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The settling out of water from cloud in the form of dew, rain, hail, snow, etc. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: atmospheric precipitation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Precipitation in the form of liquid water drops with diameters greater than 0.5 millimeter.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: rain

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A storm caused by strong rising air currents and characterized by thunder and lightning and usually heavy rain or hail. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: thunderstorm

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Breaking through the banks of a stream, thus forming a new channel or a cut-off.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: meandre drain

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The branch of physics concerned with the production, measurement, and interpretation of electromagnetic spectra arising from either emission or absorption of radiant energy by various substances. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: spectroscopy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The management of water which allows water users to receive the amount of water to which they are entitled by law and as supply permits.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water distribution

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) Zone in which precipitation is lacking to the extent that irrigation must be practised to support cultivation. 2) Zone in which average evaporation exceeds precipitation.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: arid zone

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A period of abnormally dry weather sufficiently prolonged so that the lack of water causes a serious hydrologic imbalance (such as crop damage, water supply shortage) in the affected area.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: drought

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The drainage basin of a stream. 2) An area occupied by a lake and its drainage basin.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrographic basin

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An accounting of all water inflow to, water outflow from, and changes in water storage within a hydrologic unit over a specified period.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water balance

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The physical or chemical bonding of molecules of gas, liquid or a dissolved substance to the external surface of a solid.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: adsorption

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A method of separating and analyzing mixtures of chemical substances by selective adsorption in a column of powder or on a strip of paper. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: chromatography

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: período de bajada de la crecida
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: período de bajada de la crecida
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flood return period

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The science concerned with the atmosphere and its phenomena.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: meteorology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A reciprocal transfer of individual facts, statistics or items of information between two or more parties for the purpose of enhancing knowledge of the participants. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: data exchange

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The conveyance of images, speech and other sounds, usually over great distances, through technological means, particularly by television, telegraph, telephone or radio. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: telecommunications

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A low transverse structure built in order to prevent bed erosion or raise the upstream water level.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sill

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) A soft, soupy, or muddy bottom deposit, such as found on tideland or in a stream bed. 2) A semifluid, slushy, murky mass of sediment resulting from treatment of water, sewage, or industrial and mining wastes, and often appearing as local bottom deposits in polluted bodies of water. (Source: BJGEO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sludge

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Spending by national or local government, government-owned firms or quasi-autonomous non-government organizations. (Source: ODE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: public expenditure

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: وحدة تمثل وسط متكامل التواجد الاحيائي
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mesocosme
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: وحدة تمثل وسط متكامل التواجد الاحيائي

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water that travels over the soil surface to the nearest surface stream; runoff of a drainage basin that has not passed beneath the surface since precipitation.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: surface runoff

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: That branch of physics which relates to the determination of the humidity of bodies, particularly of the atmosphere, with the theory and use of the instruments constructed for this purpose.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hygrometry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Science of the measurement and analysis of water including methods, techniques and instrumentation used in hydrology.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrometry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The measurement of the water percolating through soils and the determination of the materials dissolved by the water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: lysimetry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A device to measure humidity.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: humidity meter

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The determination of the rate of discharge at a gauging station on a stream, including an observation of `no flow', which is classed as a discharge measurement.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: discharge measurement

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The measurement of variations of level in lakes.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: limnimetry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Processes concerning living organisms.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biological process

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Sludge that has been aerated and subjected to bacterial action; used to speed breakdown of organism matter in raw sewage during secondary waste treatment. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: activated sludge

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Conversion from a liquid or solid state to a vapour.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: evaporation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Installation where impurities are removed from waste water. (Source: PHC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: purification plant

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Replacement of phosphate in detergents by environmentally safer substances, such as zeolite. The substitute will not act as a nutrient, and so will not cause eutrophication as a result of the accelerated growth of plants and microorganisms if it is released into waterways. (Source: WRIGHTa)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: phosphate removal

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) A system for burning solid carbonaceous fuel efficiently and at a relatively low temperature, thus minimizing the emission of pollutants. The fuel is crushed to very small particles or a powder and mixed with particles of an inert material. The mixture is fed into a bed through which air is pumped vertically upwards, agitating the particles so they behave like a fluid. The forced circulation of air and the small size and separation of fuel particles ensures efficient burning. 2) A bed of finely divided solid through which air or a gas is blown in a controlled manner so that it behaves as a liquid. (Source: ALL / BRACK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: fluidised bed

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: smaltimento collettivo delle acque di rifiuto
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: smaltimento collettivo delle acque di rifiuto
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: collective wastewater treatment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process of using a natural system or mechanical device to collect, treat and discharge or reclaim wastewater from an individual dwelling without the use of community-wide sewers or a centralised treatment facility. (Source: DWT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: individual wastewater treatment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: purificación del agua / depuración del agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Treatment of water (or sewage) to change harmful or undesirable physical properties and remove harmful and undesirable chemical substances and living organisms.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: purificación del agua / depuración del agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water purification

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: portata di dotazione / minimo deflusso vitale
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: portata di dotazione / minimo deflusso vitale
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: That fraction of stream flow released through a hydroelectric dam specifically to meet the needs of downstream users.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: compensation water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A process used to separate particulate solids by causing one group of particles to float; utilizes differences in surface chemical properties of the particles, some of which are entirely wetted by water, others are not. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flotation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Flowing water having its surface exposed to the atmosphere.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: open channel flow

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: catasto dei terreni e delle proprietà
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: catasto dei terreni e delle proprietà
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The system of registering certain legal estates or interests in land. It describes the land and any additional rights incidental to it, such as rights of way over adjoining land. (Source: DICLAW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: land and property register

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An investigation, especially a formal one conducted into a matter of public utility by a body constituted for that purpose by a government, local authority, or other organization. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: public inquiry
