www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: gestión del servicio de abastecimiento de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: gestión del servicio de abastecimiento de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water utility management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process of assigning or transferring authority, decision making or a specific administrative function from one entity to another. (Source: OED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: delegated management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The pursuit and killing or capture of wild animals, regarded as a sport. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hunting

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: All waters, inland or coastal, except those intended for therapeutic purposes or used in swimming pools, an area either in which bathing is explicitly authorised or in which bathing is not prohibited and is traditionally practised by a large number of bathers. Water in such areas must meet specified quality standards relating to chemical, microbiological and physical parameters. (Source: GILP96)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: bathing water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: That division of horticulture concerned with grape growing, studies of grape varieties, methods of culture, and insect and disease control. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: viticulture

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: To deprive an owner of property, especially by taking it for public use. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: expropriation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The rights of use over the property of another; a burden on a piece of land causing the owner to suffer access by another. (Source: DUHA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: easement

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The process of separating a liquid from a solid (as in waste liquid by percolation into the surrounding soil. 2) Extraction of soluble components of a solid mixture by percolating a solvent through it. 3) To lose or cause to lose soluble substances by the action of a percolating liquid. (Source: HARRIS / DICCHE / CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: leaching

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any of a group of catalytic proteins that are produced by living cells and that mediate and promote the chemical processes of life without themselves being altered or destroyed. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: enzyme

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Organic compounds containing a carboxyl group (-COOH) and an amino group (-NH2). About 30 amino acids are known. They are fundamental constituents of living matter because protein molecules are made up of many amino acid molecules combined together. Amino acids are synthesized by green plants and some bacteria, but some (arginine, histidine, lysine. threonine, methionine, isoleucine, leucine, valine, phenylalanine, tryptophane) cannot be synthesized by animals and therefore are essential constituents of their diet. Proteins from specific plants may lack certain amino acids, so a vegetarian diet must include a wide range of plant products. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: amino acid

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The principal material of inheritance. It is found in chromosomes and consists of molecules that are long unbranched chains made up of many nucleotides. Each nucleotide is a combination of phosphoric acid, the monosaccharide deoxyribose and one of four nitrogenous bases: thymine, cytosine, adenine or guanine. The number of possible arrangements of nucleotides along the DNA chain is immense. Usually two DNA strands are linked together in parallel by specific base-pairing and are helically coiled. Replication of DNA molecules is accomplished by separation of the two strands, followed by the building up of matching strands by means of base-pairing, using the two halves as templates. By a mechanism involving RNA, the structure of DNA is translated into the structure of proteins during their synthesis from amino acids. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: DNA

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A large round tower on a farm for storing grain or winter food for cattle. (Source: CAMB)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: silo

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: One of a class of compounds which contain long-chain aliphatic hydrocarbons and their derivatives, such as fatty acids, alcohols, amines, amino alcohols, and aldehydes; includes waxes, fats, and derived compounds. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: lipid

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: actor relacionado con el sector del agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: actor relacionado con el sector del agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water actor

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Measures taken to ensure an adequate supply of water and a responsible utilization of water resources. (Source: KORENa / PARCOR)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Organism which lives and obtains food at the expense of another organism, the host. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: parasite

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Microorganism known to be or is suspected of causing infection in humans, animals, or plants.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pathogenic microorganism

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Submicroscopic agents that infect plants, animals and bacteria, and are unable to reproduce outside the tissues of the host. A fully formed virus consists of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein and lipid (fat) coat. The nucleic acid of the virus interferes with nucleic acid-synthesizing mechanism of the host cell, organizing it to produce more viral nucleic acid. Viruses cause many diseases (e.g., mosaic diseases of many cultivated plants, myxomatosis, foot and mouth disease, the common cold, influenza, measles, poliomyelitis). Many plant viruses are transmitted by insects, some by eelworms. Animal viruses are spread by contact, droplet infection or by insect vectors and some are spread by the exchange of body fluids. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: virus

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The study of the mass aspects of disease. 2) The study of the occurrence and distribution of disease and injury specified by person, place, and time. (Source: MGH / KOREN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: epidemiology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: All waters on the surface of the Earth found in streams, rivers, ponds, lakes, marshes or wetlands, and as ice and snow. (Source: LANDY / BJGEO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: surface water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process by which the environment is progressively contaminated, overexploited and destroyed. (Source: RRDA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: degradation of the environment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The removal of forest and undergrowth to increase the surface of arable land or to use the timber for construction or industrial purposes. Forest and its undergrowth possess a very high water-retaining capacity, inhibiting runoff of rainwater.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: deforestation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A state of opposition or disagreement between ideas, interests, etc. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: conflict

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The expected number of lives lost, persons injured, damage to property and disruption of economic activity due to a particular natural phenomenon, and consequently the product of the probability of occurrence and the expected magnitude of damage. (Source: GUNN / RRDA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: risk

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water containing naturally or artificially supplied minerals or gases.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mineral water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water obtained from an underground formation from which water flows naturally to the surface, or would flow naturally to the surface if it were not collected underground.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: spring water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: legislación relativa al flujo de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: legislación relativa al flujo de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flow -water law

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water which has received no treatment whatsoever, or water entering a plant for further treatment.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: raw water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Aqueous solution of salts in more or less constant ratio, whose composition depends on several factors among which predominate living organisms, detrital sedimentation and the related chemical reactions. Sea-water accounts for more than 98% of the mass of the hydrosphere and covers just over 70% of the globe. Because of the composition and stability of the oceans, and the way they are controlled, they are of great importance to the climate, and great attention has been given to studying the effects of pollution. Man's activities are believed to be accelerating the change in the composition of sea-water. (Source: DODERO / WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sea water

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Water with salinity less than 0.5 (parts per thousand) dissolved salts.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: freshwater

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A community of organisms and their physical environment interacting as an ecological unit.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: ecosystem

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The study of the interrelationships between living organisms and their environment.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: ecology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The complex of atmospheric, geological and biological characteristics found in an area in the absence of artifacts or influences of a well developed technological, human culture. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: natural environment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The ability of a body of water to rid itself of pollutants. The removal of organic material, plant nutrients, or other pollutants from a lake or stream by the activity of the resident biological community. Biodegradable material added to a body of water will gradually be utilized by the microorganisms in the water, lowering the pollution levels. If excessive amounts of additional pollutants are not added downstream, the water will undergo self-cleansing. This process does not apply to pollution by non-biodegradable organic compounds or metals. (Source: NDWP)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water self-purification

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: تاثير النشاط البشري في محيطة البيئي
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: anthropization
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: تاثير النشاط البشري في محيطة البيئي

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The potential of an organic substance to be broken down into simpler compounds or molecules through the action of microorganisms.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biodegradability

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An essential nutrient in the food supply of plants and the diets of animals. Animals obtain it in nitrogen-containing compounds, particularly amino acids. Although the atmosphere is nearly 80% gaseous nitrogen, very few organisms have the ability to use it in this form. The higher plants normally obtain it from the soil after micro-organisms have converted the nitrogen into ammonia or nitrates, which they can then absorb. (Source: WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: nitrogen

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A reduction in water quality caused by increasing its temperature, often due to disposal of waste heat from industrial or power generation processes. Thermally polluted water can harm the environment because plants and animals can have a hard time adapting to it. (Source: WEBRIV)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: thermal pollution

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The use of materials, processes, and practices that reduce or eliminate the creation of pollutants or wastes at the source. Examples of pollution prevention activities include inventory management/purchasing procedures, source reduction, process modifications, ousekeeping/good operating practices, material substitutions, redesign of product, pollution prevention education/outreach, and in-process recycling. Disposal, off site recycling or reprocessing of astes is not pollution prevention. (Source: P2AD)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pollution prevention

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Pollution by toxic substances that produce a harmful effect on living organisms by physical contact, ingestion, or inhalation.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: toxic pollution

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The removal of water or any soluble constituents from the soil. Leaching often occurs with soil constituents such as nitrate fertilizers with the result that nitrates end up in potable waters.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: soil leaching

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The more or less decomposed organic matter in the soil. Besides being the source of most of the mineral salts needed by plants, humus improves the texture of the soil and holds water, so reducing the loss of nutrients by leaching. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: humus

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The gathering and studying of data to determine the projection of demand for an item or service. (Source: ISEP / RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: market study

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An investigative technique using a mathematical or physical representation of a system or theory that accounts for all or some its known properties. Models are often used to test the effect of changes of system components on the overall performance of the system. (Source: LEE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: modelling

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A game played on a large open course, the object of which is to hit a ball using clubs, with as few strokes as possible, into each of usually 18 holes.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: golf

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The complex of individual or group activities pursued for exercise or pleasure, often taking a competitive form. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sport

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A group of establishments engaged in the same or similar kinds of economic activities. Industries produce commodities that are sold with the expectation of recovering the total cost of production. A single industry can produce many different commodities.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: industry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An organism that has undergone external processes by which its basic set of genes has been altered. (Source: LEE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: genetically modified organism

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Industry related with the production of chemical compounds. The chemical processing industry has a variety of special pollution problems due to the vast number of products manufactured. The treatment processes combine processing, concentration, separation, extraction, by-product recovery, destruction, and reduction in concentration. The wastes may originate from solvent extraction, acid and caustic wastes, overflows, spills, mechanical loss, etc. (Source: PZ)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: chemical industry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Industry related to the extraction of solid mineral resources from the earth.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mining industry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The excess, unusable semi-solids or sediment resulting from a wastewater treatment or industrial process. (Source: RHW / TOE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: residual waste sludge

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The administration, promotion, organization and planning for the business or industry of providing information, transportation, entertainment, accommodations and other services to travelers or visitors. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: touristic activity management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: ressource captage et distribution de l'eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: ressource captage et distribution de l'eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: resource, collecting and water distribution

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A method of obtaining pure water from water containing a salt, as in desalination. Pure water and the salt water are separated by a semipermeable membrane and the pressure of the salt water is raised above the osmotic pressure, causing water from the brine to pass through the membrane into the pure water. This process requires a pressure of some 25 atmospheres, which makes it difficult to apply on a large scale. (Source: DICCHE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: reverse osmosis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Physical and chemical processes for making water suitable for human consumption and other purposes. The treatment processes of greatest importance are sedimentation, coagulation, filtration, disinfection, softening and aeration.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water treatment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Sludge or thickened mixture of sewage solids with water that has been decomposed by anaerobic bacteria. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: digested sludge

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A place near the sea where people spend their holidays and enjoy themselves. (Source: CAMB)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: seaside resort

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The collaboration between governments, businesses or individuals in which it is agreed to work together on similar objectives or strategies, particularly in research or in setting industrial standards. (Source: ODE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: international co-operation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An examination using one or more of the senses (e.g. sight, smell, etc.).
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: organoleptic analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Analysis based on the physical changes associated with chemical reactions.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: physicochemical analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Farming without the use of industrially made fertilizers or pesticides. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: organic farming

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_en: exploitation of non renewable water resources
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: استثمار واستغلال مصادر الماء الغير المتجددة
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: sfruttamento della risorsa idrica non rinnovabile
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: exploitation de la ressource en eau non renouvelable
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: exploitation de la ressource en eau non renouvelable
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: sfruttamento della risorsa idrica non rinnovabile
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: exploitation of non renewable water resources
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: استثمار واستغلال مصادر الماء الغير المتجددة
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_en: exploitation of non renewable water resources

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Study of the chemical, physical and biological properties of water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Analysis for the identification of viruses, bacteria, fungi and parasites.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: microbiological analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process by which plants transform carbon dioxide and water into carbohydrates and other compounds, using energy from the sun captured by chlorophyll in the plant. Oxygen is a by-product of the process. Photosynthesis is the essence of all plant life (autotrophic production) and hence of all animal life (heterotrophic production) on the planet Earth. The rate of photosynthesis depends on climate, intensity and duration of sunlight, available leaf area, soil nutrient availability, temperature, carbon dioxide concentration, and soil moisture regimes. (Source: DUNSTE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: photosynthesis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Lakes created behind manmade barriers.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: artificial lake

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A green pigment, present in algae and higher plants, that absorbs light energy and thus plays a vital role in photosynthesis. Except in Cyanophyta (blue-green algae), chlorophyll is confined to chloroplasts. There are several types of chlorophyll, but all contain magnesium and iron. Some plants (e.g., brown algae, red algae, copper beech trees) contain additional pigments that masks the green of their chlorophyll. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: chlorophyll

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: red de suministro de agua potable
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: red de suministro de agua potable
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water supply network

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The physical location or type of environment in which an organism or biological population lives or occurs. 2) The place occupied by an organism, population, or community. It is the physical part of the community structure in which an organism finds its home, and includes the sum total of all the environmental conditions present in the specific place occupied by an organism. Often a habitat is defined to include a whole community of organisms. (Source: HABIT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: habitat

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: مخلفات متهالكة من اغصان وجذوع الاشجار المتراكمة في المجرى المائي
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The choking of a stream channel by the piling up of ice against an obstruction, forming a temporary dam; an accumulation of ice at a given location which, in a river, restricts the flow of water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: ice jam
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: مخلفات متهالكة من اغصان وجذوع الاشجار المتراكمة في المجرى المائي

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: وحدة جغرافية ارضية مائية دولية متناسقة
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: international hydrographic district
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: وحدة جغرافية ارضية مائية دولية متناسقة

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: وحدة جغرافية ارضية مائية متكاملة ومرجعية
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: reference hydrographical unit
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: وحدة جغرافية ارضية مائية متكاملة ومرجعية

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: حوض جغرافي ثانوي الحجم لمصبات مائية متعددة
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: subwatershed
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: حوض جغرافي ثانوي الحجم لمصبات مائية متعددة

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Software is the general term used to describe all of the various programs that may be used on a computer system. Software can be divided into four main categories: systems software, development software, user interface software, applications software. (Source: POPTEL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: software

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The study of chemical substances occurring in living organisms and the reactions and methods for identifying these substances. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biochemistry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Those organisms attached to, living on, in or near the sea bed, river bed or lake floor. (Source: LBC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: benthos

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Addition of air to sewage or water so as to raise its dissolved oxygen level.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water aeration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A computer configuration of hardware and software that simulates the judgment and behavior of a human or an organization with extensive knowledge in a particular field, often by giving answers, solutions or diagnoses. (Source: RHW / WIC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: expert system

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The property of having excess hydroxide ions in solution.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: alkalinity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A nonmetallic element used to manufacture phosphoric acid, in phosphor bronzes, incendiaries, pyrotechnics, matches, and rat poisons; the white or yellow allotrope is a soft waxy solid, soluble in carbon disulfide, insoluble in water and alcohol, and is poisonous and self-igniting in air; the red allotrope is an amorphous powder, insoluble in all solvents and is nonpoisonous; the black allotrope comprises lustrous crystals similar to graphite, and is insoluble in most solvents. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: phosphorus

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Plant and animal residue that decomposes and becomes a part of the soil.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: organic matter

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The state of being acid that is of being capable of transferring a hydrogen ion in solution.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: acidity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A building directly used in manufacturing or technically productive enterprises. Industrial buildings are not generally or typically accessible to other than workers. Industrial buildings include buildings used directly in the production of power, the manufacture of products, the mining of raw materials, and the storage of textiles, petroleum products, wood and paper products, chemicals, plastics, and metals. (Source: JJK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: industrial building

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Buildings, equipment and services provided for a community. (Source: CAMB)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: community facility

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A room or building with scientific equipment for doing scientific tests or for teaching science, or a place where chemicals or medicines are produced. (Source: CAMB)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: laboratory

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A place in the mountains where people spend their holidays and enjoy themselves. (Source: CAMB)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mountain resort

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Guarded area equipped with sanitary facilities where holiday-makers may pitch a tent and camp by paying a daily rate. (Source: ZINZAN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: camping

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: aziende per la fornitura di servizi
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: aziende per la fornitura di servizi
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: services providing company

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Portion of the river bed that is occupied by water only in the event of floods.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flood channel

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Stream channel occupied during periods of low flow.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: low-flow channel

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A small stream or rivulet, commonly swiftly flowing in rugged terrain, of lesser length and volume than a creek; especially a stream that issues directly from the ground, as from a spring or seep, or that is produced by heavy rainfall or melting snow.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: brook

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A fast, short stream of water with strong changes in flow.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: torrent

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: One curved portion of a sinuous or winding stream channel, consisting of two consecutive loops, one turning clockwise and the other anticlockwise.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: meander

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Use of water that allows its evaporation or makes it unfit for any subsequent use.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water consumption

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The intertidal zone of the seashore. (Source: LBC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: littoral

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Summit or boundary line separating adjacent drainage basins.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: watershed divide

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Development that provides economic, social and environmental benefits in the long term having regard to the needs of living and future generations. Defined by the World Commission on Environment and Development in 1987 as: development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. (Source: GILP96)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sustainable development

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The coming together in accord of two minds on a given proposition. In law, a concord of understanding and intention between two or more parties with respect to the effect upon their relative rights and duties, of certain past or future facts or performances. The consent of two or more persons concerning respecting the transmission of some property, right, or benefits, with the view of contracting an obligation, a mutual obligation. (Source: WESTS)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: agreement (legal)

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: exploitation de la ressource en eau renouvelable
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: exploitation de la ressource en eau renouvelable
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: exploitation of renewable water resources

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Farming in which as much use is made of the land as possible by growing crops close together or by growing several crops in a year or by using large amounts of fertilizers. (Source: PHC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: intensive farming

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The temperature of the atmosphere which represents the average kinetic energy of the molecular motion in a small region and is defined in terms of a standard or calibrated thermometer in thermal equilibrium with the air. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: air temperature

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A formal written record of transactions, proceedings, etc., as of a society, committee, or legislative body. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: chart (act)

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A general term for chemical agents that are used in order to kill unwanted plants, animals pests or disease-causing fungi, and embracing insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, nematicides, etc. Some pesticides have had widespread disruptive effects among non-target species. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pesticide

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Governance has many dimensions: creating a fair legal, policy and regulatory framework in which the rights of people to access resources are secured; improving the effectiveness, accountability and transparency of government agencies; ensuring the participation of the poor in decision making; enhancing the role of civil society; ensuring basic security and political freedoms; and others.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: Governance

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A narrow depositional feature, such as a spit, barrier, or bar, built out from the shore of a sea or lake by the action of waves and currents that deposits excess material at its deep end; it may be merged or submerged.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: embankment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A stage of growth or advancement in any aspect of a community that is defined by or restricted to a particular and usually small district or area. (Source: RHW / ISEP)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: local development

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The property of a substance affecting the sense of smell; any smell; scent; perfume. (Source: LEE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: odour

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A gaseous suspension of ultramicroscopic particles of a liquid or a solid. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: aerosol

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any substance, usually a residue of human activity, which has an undesirable effect upon the environment. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pollutant

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Pollutant which exists in very small traces in water. (Source: PHC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: micropollutant

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The long-term fluctuations in temperature, precipitation, wind, and all other aspects of the Earth's climate. External processes, such as solar-irradiance variations, variations of the Earth's orbital parameters (eccentricity, precession, and inclination), lithosphere motions, and volcanic activity, are factors in climatic variation. Internal variations of the climate system, e.g., changes in the abundance of greenhouse gases, also may produce fluctuations of sufficient magnitude and variability to explain observed climate change through the feedback processes interrelating the components of the climate system. (Source: GSFC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: Climatic change

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The flow of commodities and goods between nations. (Source: GOOD)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: international trade

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Controlled release of water from a reservoir.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: dam release

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The general drift, tendency, or bent of a set of statistical data as related to time or another related set of statistical data. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: trend

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A type of climate characterized by hot, dry, sunny summers and a winter rainy season; basically, this is the opposite of a monsoon climate. Also known as etesian climate. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: Mediterranean climate

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The measurement of depths of water in oceans, seas and lakes; also the information derived from such measurements.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: bathymetry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A system using beamed and reflected radiofrequency energy for detecting and locating objects, measuring distance or altitude, navigating, homing, bombing and other purposes. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: radar

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The science of measurement. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: metrology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The generic name for a device that senses either the absolute value or a change in a physical quantity such as temperature, pressure, flow rate, or pH, or the intensity of light, sound, or ratio waves and converts that change into a useful input signal for an information-gathering system. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sensor

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An instrument for recording the quantity of water passing through a particular outlet.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water meter

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The application of scientific methods and engineering principles to civil engineering problems through acquiring, interpreting, and using knowledge of materials of the crust of the earth. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: geotechnics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: مطرح مياة المجمعات الحضرية لموسم الجفاف
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: dry weather urban runoff
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: مطرح مياة المجمعات الحضرية لموسم الجفاف

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any of several techniques such as radioactive dating, dendrochronology, or varve dating, for establishing the age of rocks, palaeontological or archaeological specimens, etc. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: dating

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The determination of the different grain size in a granular material. 2) The proportion by weight of particles of different sizes in granular material. (Source: ECHO2)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: granulometry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any method of several of seeing what is beneath the surface of the ground, without actually disturbing the ground.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: geophysical prospecting

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Well tapping a confined or artesian aquifer in which the static water level stands above the surface of the ground.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: artesian well

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A hole dug into the earth to reach a supply of water, oil, brine or gas. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: well

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The act or activity of restoring groundwater to its original condition, or to certain minimum standards established by federal, state or tribal government.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: groundwater restoration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any monetary grant made by the government to a private industrial undertaking or charitable organization, but especially one given to consumers or producers in order to lower the market price of some service or product and make it readily affordable to the public. (Source: MGHME / RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: subsidy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The market condition where an individual or firm that wants to buy or sell a commodity or service has a choice of possible suppliers or customers. (Source: ODE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic competition

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: In economics, the value of the factors of production used by a firm in producing or distributing goods and services or engaging in both activities. (Source: GREENW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: cost

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: صدمة مائية داخل انبوب عند الغلق الفجائي
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A waterhammer is created by stopping and/or starting a liquid flow suddenly. The results of a waterhammer or impulse load are devastating to a pressure sensor. The impulse load occurs suddenly, in the millisecond time frame, but the effects of it last a life time. The hammer occurs because an entire train of water is being stopped so fast that the end of the train hits up against the front end and sends shock waves through the pipe. (Source: OMEGA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water hammer
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: صدمة مائية داخل انبوب عند الغلق الفجائي

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A tube made of metal, clay, plastic, wood, or concrete and used to conduct a fluid, gas, or finely divided solid.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: pipe

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A global consortium of local computer networks that uses the TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) protocol to connect machines to each other, providing access to the World Wide Web, Gopher, electronic mail, remote login and file transfer. (Source: WON)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: internet

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any means of communication transmitted to both the sense of hearing and the sense of sight, especially technologies directed to large audiences. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: audiovisual media

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The obligation to answer for an act done, and to repair or otherwise make restitution for any injury it may have caused. (Source: WESTS)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: responsibility

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Detachment and movement of topsoil or soil material from the upper part of the profile, by the action of wind or running water, especially as a result of changes brought about by human activity, such as unsuitable or mismanaged agriculture.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: soil erosion

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process of forming visible images directly or indirectly by the action of light or other forms of radiation on sensitive surfaces. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: photography

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: amélioration de la qualité de l'eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: mejora de la calidad del agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: amélioration de la qualité de l'eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Progress in, or betterment of, the environmental condition and integrity of water. (Source: RHW / TOE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: mejora de la calidad del agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water quality improvement

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A graded value of the components (organic and inorganic, chemical or physical) which comprise the nature of water. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water quality

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A measure of water quality based on biological diversity and water quality-including levels of dissolved oxygen, coliform bacteria, oxygen-demanding substances, and nutrients.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: quality index

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any of a class of high-molecular weight polymer compounds composed of a variety of alfa-amino acids joined by peptide linkages. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: protein

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Station where the presence, effect, or level of any polluting substance in air or water, noise and blasting, radiation, transport movements, land subsidence, or change in the character of vegetation are measured quantitatively or qualitatively.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: monitoring station

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: To check regularly in order to perceive change in some quality or quantity. (Source: BRACK)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: monitoring

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A minute quantity of radioactive isotope used in medicine or biology to study the chemical changes within living tissues. (Source: KOREN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: tracer

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The scientific detection, recognition, inventory and analysis of land and water area by the use of distant sensors or recording devices such as photography, thermal scanners, radar, etc. 2) Complex of techniques for the remote measure of electromagnetic energy emitted by objects. (Source: LANDY / ZINZAN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: remote sensing

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The analysis of a substance in order to ascertain its influence on living organisms. (Source: PHCa)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biological analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Examination or determination. (Source: RRDA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A species or organism that is used to grade environmental quality or change.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: biological indicator

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Summit or boundary line separating adjacent drainage basins.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: watershed

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The use of standard acid solutions to determine the concentration of basic solutions of unknown normality.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: alkalimetry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Cloudy or hazy appearance in a naturally clear liquid caused by a suspension of colloidal liquid droplets or fine solids.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: turbidity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A chemical substance, produced by microorganisms and synthetically, that has the capacity to inhibit the growth of, and even to destroy, bacteria and other microorganisms. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: antibiotic

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A sub-group of coliforms, found almost exclusively in the intestinal wastes of humans and animals, and seldom found elsewhere in the environment. If detected in water, good indicator that the water has been contaminated by sewage or improperly treated. (Source: SEPTIC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: fecal coliform

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Impairment of water quality to a degree which reduces the usability of the water for ordinary purposes, or which creates a hazard to public health through poisoning or spread of disease.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water contamination

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The maximum amount of discharge legally allowed from a single source, mobile or stationary. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: emission standard

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Part of a global emergency plan which describes mainly the information transfer and the alerting procedures.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: alarm plan

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The high probability that a given hazard or situation will yield a significant amount of lives lost, persons injured, damage to property , disruption of economic activity or harm to the environment; or any product of the probability of occurrence and the expected magnitude of damage beyond a maximum acceptable level. (Source: TOE / HMD)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: major risk

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flooding

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Measures that identify, acquire, and plan the use of resources needed to anticipate, prevent, and and/or resolve a threat to public safety.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: crisis management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The state of combustion in which inflammable material burns, producing heat, flames and often smoke. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: fire

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An anticipatory emergency plan to be followed in an expected or eventual disaster, based on risk assessment, availability of human and material resources, community preparedness, local and international response capability, etc.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: first aid plan

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The vulnerability of the area in terms of expected number of lives lost, persons injured, damage to property and disruption of economic activity due to a natural hazard. In other words, a natural azard becomes a natural risk when population and property might be affected. (Source: ILWIS)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: natural risk

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Violent, sudden and destructive change in the environment without cause from human activity, due to phenomena such as floods, earthquakes, fire and hurricanes.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: natural catastrophe

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Area of land on which sewage or any other type of waste water is distributed in order to purify it; it is a kind of waste water treatment. (Source: RRDA / ECHO2)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sewage farm

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A program of action designed to reach a given set of objectives. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: management plan

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_en: water resource development and management outlines
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water resource development and management outlines
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_en: water resource development and management outlines

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Consideration, commentary by argument or informal debate on some issue that is open and of concern to the general populace. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: public discussion

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Collection of legislation, legal interpretations, governmental decisions, agency rules and regulations, and cultural responses which guide a country's actions concerning the quantity and quality of water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water policy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: gestion patrimoniale et econome de l'eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: gestion patrimoniale et econome de l'eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A type of leadership and management style attempting to gain the loyalty and support of subordinates by excessively providing for their needs and interests.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: patrimonial management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any salt or ester of nitric acid, such as sodium nitrate. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: nitrate

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Essential nutrient of the food supply of plants and the diets of animals. Animals obtain it in nitrogen-containing compounds, particularly aminoacids. Although the atmosphere is nearly 80% gaseous nitrogen, very few organisms have the ability to use it in this form. The higher plants normally obtain it from the soil after microorganisms have converted the nitrogen into ammonia or nitrates, which they can then absorb. This conversion of nitrogen, known as nitrogen fixation, is essential for the formation of amino acids which, in turn, are the building blocks of proteins. (Source: WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: organic nitrogen

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any of various processes, either sexual or asexual, by which an animal produces one or more individuals similar to itself. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: animal reproduction

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Taste in water can be caused by foreign matter, such as organic compounds, inorganic salts or dissolved gases. These materials may come from domestic, agricultural or natural sources. Some substances found naturally in groundwater, while not necessarily harmful, may impart a disagreeable taste or undesirable property to the water. Magnesium sulphate, sodium sulphate, and sodium chloride are but a few of these. Acceptable waters should be free from any objectionable taste at point of use. (Source: CORBIT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water taste

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Properties relating to the senses (taste, color, odor, feel).
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: organoleptic characteristic

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Site which is declared protected because of its natural, landscape, artistic or archeological features in order to guarantee its conservation, maintenance and restoration.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: classified site

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The study of bodies of fresh water with reference to their plant and animal life, physical properties, geographical and geological features.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: limnology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Zone in which precipitation exceeds potential evaporation.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: humid zone

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The study of the effect of forces on liquids.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: fluid mechanics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Generally, the world's natural resources as handed down to the present generation, and specifically, the earth's outstanding physical, biological and geological formations, and habitats of threatened species of animals and plants and areas with scientific, conservation or aesthetic value. (Source: WHC / OED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: natural heritage

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The branch of science and technology concerned with the mechanics of fluids, especially liquids.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydraulics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Sizing or classifying particulate matter by suspension in a fluid (liquid or gas), the larger particulates tending to separate by sinking.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: decantation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The level reached by the surface of a body of water. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water level

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Areas of a country where special measures may be given to protect the natural habitats which present a high level of vulnerability.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: sensible area

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The production of plants and animals useful to man, involving soil cultivation and the breeding and management of crops and livestock.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: agriculture

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: شبكة انهار قنوات مياة ذات مُعطيات بيانية مائية
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The configuration or arrangement in plan view of the natural stream courses in an area. It is related to local geologic and geomorphologic features and history. Synonym: drainage pattern.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrographic network
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: شبكة انهار قنوات مياة ذات مُعطيات بيانية مائية

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A source or volume of water available for use; also, the system of reservoirs, wells, conduits, and treatment facilities required to make the water available and usable. (Source: BJGEO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water supply

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A balance sheet or statement of estimated receipts and expenditures. A plan for the coordination of resource and expenditures. The amount of money that is available for, required for, or assigned to a particular purpose. (Source: WESTS)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: budget

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: تصحيح العرض في حاله إنخفاض المستوى الهيكلي للمياه
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: zona de distribución de las aguas
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: zona de distribución de las aguas
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water distribution area
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: تصحيح العرض في حاله إنخفاض المستوى الهيكلي للمياه

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Safe places where animals escape from predators, find shelter from weather extremes, and bear and raise offspring.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: reproduction area

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The degree of dissolved salts in water measured by weight in parts per thousand. (Source: KOREN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water salinity

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The energetic state of a system at any given time. (Source: WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: energy balance

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The strategy for reducing energy requirements per unit of industrial output or individual well-being without affecting the progress of socio-economic development or causing disruption in life style. In temperate developed countries most energy is used in heating and lighting industrial and domestic buildings. Industrial processes, transport and agriculture are the other main users. During the 1970s it was demonstrated that substantial savings could be achieved through appropriate building technologies and the use of energy-efficient equipment for heating, air-conditioning and lighting. Most goods could and should be both manufactured and made to work more efficiently. (Source: WRIGHT)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: energy conservation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A heavily irrigated or lightly flooded piece of land in which rice is grown.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: paddy field

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Land degradation in arid, semi-arid and dry sub-humid areas resulting from various factors, including climatic variations and human activities. Patches of degraded land may develop hundreds of kilometres from the nearest desert. But these patches can expand and join together, creating desert-like conditions. Desertification contributes to other environmental crises, such as the loss of biodiversity and global warming. Drought often triggers desertification, but human activities are usually the most significant causes. Over-cultivation exhausts the soil. Overgrazing removes vegetation that prevents soil erosion. Trees that bind the soil together are cut for lumber or firewood for heating and cooking. Poorly drained irrigation turns cropland salty, desertifying 500,000 hectares annually, about the same amount of soil that is newly irrigated each year. (Source: ECOSOC)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: desertification

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The rate at which electric energy is converted to other forms of energy, equal to the product of the current and the voltage drop. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: electric power

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Energy released by nuclear fission or nuclear fusion. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: nuclear energy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any spending done by a person living alone or by a group of people living together in shared accommodation and with common domestic expenses. (Source: ODE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: household expenditure

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The actual unit cost of water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water cost

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Inorganic materials having a distinct chemical composition, characteristic crystalline structure, colour, and hardness.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: mineral matter

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Procurement of monetary resources or credit to operate a business or acquire assets. (Source: WESTS)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: financing

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Separation of particles from a suspension in a centrifuge: balanced tubes containing the suspension are attached to the opposite ends of arms rotating rapidly about a central point; the suspended particles are forced outwards, and collect at the bottoms of the tubes. (Source: UVAROV)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: centrifugation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: All activities whereby such structures or mechanisms like dams, wells, storage tanks, cisterns, channels, aqueducts, pipes, storm drains and sewers are used to collect, channel, divert or extract water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water catchment

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: That body of the law that deals with conduct considered so harmful to society as a whole that it is prohibited by statute, prosecuted and punished by the government. (Source: DUHA)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: criminal law

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The purported, collective view of the public on some issue or problem, typically formulated by selective polling or sampling, and frequently used as a guide to action or decision. (Source: RHW / ISEP)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: public opinion

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Reclamation of effluent generated by a given user for on-site reuse by the same user. See: water reuse.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water recycling

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Structures, as roads, dams, or post offices, paid for by government funds for public use.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: public works

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A material applied onto or impregnated into a substrate for protective, decorative, or functional purposes. Such materials include, but are not limited to, paints, varnishes, sealers, adhesives, thinners, diluents, and inks. (Source: LEE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: coating

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Use of process wastewater or treatment facility effluent in a different manufacturing process. (Source: LEE)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water reuse

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A building allocated for residence. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: residential building

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: regolazione fisica di un corso d'acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: planificación física de los cursos de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: regolazione fisica di un corso d'acqua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: planificación física de los cursos de agua
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: river physical arrangement

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any mechanical procedure or process where some or all of the salt is removed from water.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water desalination

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: اعادة تهذيب وتحديد مسلك المجرى المائي
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: River engineering measures taken to realign a natural water course (straightening, diversion, meander cut-off).
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: river training
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: اعادة تهذيب وتحديد مسلك المجرى المائي

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A branch of mathematics dealing with the collection, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of masses of numerical data. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: statistics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The body of techniques used in statistical inference concerning a population. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: statistical analysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A representation of a problem, situation in mathematical terms, especially using a computer. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: simulation

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: فحص التطويف وتخثير العوالق في الماء
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: jar test
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: فحص التطويف وتخثير العوالق في الماء

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any tool or method used by an organization to achieve general developmental goals in the production of, or in the regulation of, material resources. (Source: OED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: economic instrument

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An accounting of all water inflows to, water outflows from, and changes in water storage within a hydrologic unit over a specified period of time.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: hydrologic balance

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Discharge of water from the earth's surface to the atmosphere by evaporation from lakes, streams and soil surfaces and by transpiration from plants. Also known as fly-off. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: evapotranspiration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: 1) The downward entry of water into soil. Also called percolation. A high rate of infiltration means that soil moisture for crops will be higher. Many conservation practices, such as conservation tillage, reduce rates of runoff and increase infiltration rates. 2) The flow of a fluid into a substance through pores or small openings. It connotes flow into a substance in contradistinction to the word percolation, which connotes flow through a porous substance. (Source: ILRDSS)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: water infiltration

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any technique by which an unknown colour is evaluated in terms of standard colours; the technique may be visual, photoelectric or indirect by means of spectrophotometry. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: colourimetry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_es: apoyo a la toma de decisiones
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_es: apoyo a la toma de decisiones
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: decision making support

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: All the chemical reactions that take place in a living organism, comprising both anabolism and catabolism. Basal metabolism is the energy exchange of an animal at rest. Catabolism is the synthesis of complex molecules from simpler ones. Catabolism is the breaking down by organisms of complex molecules into simpler ones with the liberation of energy. (Source: ALL)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: metabolism

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A salt or ester of nitric acid, included in compounds such as potassium nitrite, sodium nitrite and butyl nitrite. (Source: RHW)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: nitrite

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The system of methods and principles used in a particular discipline. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: methodology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The principles and procedures of soil management and of field crop and special-purpose plant improvement, management, and production. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: agronomy

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The management of forest lands for wood, forages, water, wildlife, and recreation. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: forestry

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A critical examination of facts or conditions to provide information on a situation. Usually conducted by interviews and/or on-site visitations. (Source: LANDY)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: survey

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A substance that continues to occupy in a continuous manner the whole of the space in which it is placed, however large or small this place is made, the temperature remaining constant.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: gas

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The process of removing a sorbed substance by the reverse of adsorption or absorption. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: desorption

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Addition of an acid to a solution until the pH falls below 7.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: acidification

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A change in which a substance is transformed into one or more new substances. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: chemical reaction

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: One or two or more atoms with the same atomic number that contain different numbers of neutrons. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: isotope

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The branch of engineering concerned with industrial manufacture of chemical products. It is a discipline in which the principles of mathematical, physical and natural sciences are used to solve problems in applied chemistry. Chemical engineers design, develop, and optimise processes and plants, operate them, manage personnel and capital, and conduct research necessary for new developments. Through their efforts, new petroleum products, plastics, agricultural chemicals, house-hold products, pharmaceuticals, electronic and advanced materials, photographic materials, chemical and biological compounds, various food and other products evolve. (Source: USTa)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: chemical engineering

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A phenomenon in which a relatively small amount of substance augments the rate of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: catalysis

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The side slopes of a channel between which the streamflow is normally confined.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: streambank

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A natural stream arising in a given drainage basin but not wholly dependent for its flow on surface drainage in its immediate area, flowing in a channel with a well-defined bed between visible banks or through a definite depression in the land, having a definite and permanent or periodic supply of water, and usually, but not necessarily, having a perceptible current in a particular direction and discharging at a fixed point into another body of water. (Source: BJGEO)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: watercourse

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Stretch of river, its banks and the land nearby. The width of the its banks and the land nearby. The width of the corridor depends on how much surrounding land is affected by the river and vice versa.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: river corridor

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Any watery environment, from small to large, from pond to ocean, in which plants and animals interact with the chemical and physical features of the environment.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: aquatic ecosystem

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Substance, element or compound necessary for the growth and development of plants and animals.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: nutrient

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Science and technique of data elaboration and of automatic treatment of information. (Source: ZINZAN)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: informatics

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_ar: تفرُع مائي آسن غير متجدد وميت
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A small arc-shaped lake that represents part of the former course of a river. It is an abandoned meander. Oxbows are only found on river floodplains.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: oxbow lake
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_ar: تفرُع مائي آسن غير متجدد وميت

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Auxiliary spillway designed to carry excess runoff from the design storm once the temporary storage volume is filled. Sometimes referred to as an emergency spillway.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: flood spillway

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Curved masonry or concrete dam, convex in shape upstream, that depends on arch action for its stability; the load or water pressure is transferred by the arch to the abutments.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: arch dam

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A concrete structure proportioned so that its own weight provides the major resistance to the forces exerted on it.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: gravity dam

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: Length of open channel between two defined cross-sections.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: reach

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The drawing of water from a reservoir by means of draining pipes located at the bottom of the basin and controlled by a system of sluices which ensure, if necessary, the emptying of the basin in a given period of time in respect of downstream conditions.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: dam draining

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: canale di cacciata di una diga
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: canale di cacciata di una diga
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: barrage drive away

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_it: la gestione integrata delle fonte di acqua dolce
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_fr: gestion integree de la ressource en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objectname_fr: gestion integree de la ressource en eau
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.objecttrans_it: la gestione integrata delle fonte di acqua dolce
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: integrated water resource management

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A regional climate which is under the predominant influence of the sea, that is, a climate characterized by oceanity; the antithesis of a continental climate.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: oceanic climate

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: That branch of meteorology concerned with the mean physical state of the atmosphere together with its statistical variations in both space and time as reflected in the weather behaviour over a period of many years. (Source: MGH)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: climatology

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: A climate characterized by hot summers, cold winters, and little rainfall, typical of the interior of a continent. (Source: CED)
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: continental climate

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: An atmospheric disturbance involving perturbations of the prevailing pressure and wind fields on scales ranging from tornadoes to extratropical cyclones; also the associated weather and the like.
www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.name: storm

www.semide.net_portal_thesaurus_Concept_.definition: The violent shaking of the ground produced by deep seismic waves, beneath the epicentre, generated by a sudden decrease or release in a volume of rock of elastic strain accumulated over a long time in regions of seismic activity (tectonic earthquake).
